intro: Trigynia, commonly known as the "three-woman plant," is a genus of flowering plants in the family Scrophulariaceae. It is characterized by its unique floral structure, featuring three stigmas that are often mistaken for separate flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is native to regions in the Mediterranean and parts of Asia. Trigynia species are known for their small, tubular flowers that are often brightly colored to attract pollinators. These plants are generally hardy and can thrive in a variety of environmental conditions.
